ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] URI length restriction
ygData.msgSnippet: Yes, good point. If SOAP 1.2 with the WebMethod enables GET, which would have the benefit of enabling cache intermediaries, then why isn t is used more often?

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Yes, good point. If SOAP 1.2 with the WebMethod enables GET, which would ha=
ve the benefit of enabling cache intermediaries, then why isn't is used mor=
e often? Ref: Stefan (Tilkov) points out in [*] that SOAP 1.2 is just not u=
sed very much in practice. 

[*] http://www.parleys.com/display/PARLEYS/Hom=
e#;slide=3D6;talk=3D31817742





________________________________
From: Ph=
ilippe Mougin <pmougin@...>
To: Rest Discussion Group <rest-discuss@yah=
oogroups.com>
Cc: Sean Kennedy <seandkennedy@...>
Sent: Thursday, 3=
0 July, 2009 15:29:57
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] URI length restriction


=
Le 30 juil. 09 =E0 14:46, Sean Kennedy a =E9crit :

> Yes, I agree, the uni=
form interface should be maintained. In other words, if the SOAP message is=
 "updateCustomer" then that should map to a PUT, "addCutomer" should map to=
 a POST, "deleteCustomer" to DELETE and "getCustomer" to a GET.
> The key i=
s that SOAP POSTs "get" (and "delete") type requests which I think should b=
e mapped to a RESTful GET (and DELETE).

Note that SOAP is now able to use =
GET to do a get. See SOAP 1.2 - HTTP GET usage (http://www.w3.org/TR/soap12=
-part0/#L26854).

Philippe Mougin
